item.description: 1 Introduction 2 Prepare 3 Get started 3.1 Population vs Sample 3.2 How to infer from a sample to a population 3.2.1 Normal Distrubution 3.2.2 Central Tendency 3.2.3 Dispersion 3.2.4 Confidence interval 3.2.5 Z-score 3.2.6 skew and kurtosis analysis 3.2.7 Hypothesis Testing 3.2.8 Shapiroâ€“Wilk test 3.2.9 Using Normal Distribution to find outliers 3.3 Missing Data 3.4 More 4 Explore 5 Analysis 6 Model 7 Report 8 Using R References 1 Introduction 2 Prepare We explore a student exam performance data set.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.
